commentBody:
Said one abacus to the other, "You can count on me!"

(No bead to worry!)

I started out slow and was afraid this one might get me. But it turns out the NW corner was the toughest part. The rest fell into place pretty easily, and I was able to circle back and do the beginning at the end.
Had "arboretum" for 17A at first.

Nice fill, solid grid, and some nice clues.

But this was too easy for a Friday 

5/10

This one caused me great difficulty.  I was poking around with only a few stray answers and thinking I might have to sleep on it, when I hit on YOUCANCOUNTONME.  That opened up most of the puzzle, except for the stubborn NW corner.  I couldn’t come up with STOWE, and instead fixated on Scott, as in Sir Walter, which led me to think the grocery pricing term was tare, and I was not up on my microscope parts.  I did get there eventually. 

 I also wanted stick around a campsite to be kindling, but didn’t cling to that one too long

TIL that  a nutrix is a WETNURSE and encountered the term UNDIERUNS for the first (and hopefully last) time.

Very satisfying Friday exercise.
I suppose an UNDIE RUN is an event for streakers with scruples.
I stared at BESTRONG for a long, long time.

I finished the puzzle and looked back through the clues for any entries that I had just gotten on the crosses. I was scratching my head on 55A. UN-DIE RUNS? Was this some gamer slang for when you make it through a level without using up any of your lives?

And then I figured it out.

Fine puzzle, very fluid. Love wet nurse crossing arid -- that'll wean you pretty quick!

You can count on me seemed eerily familiar. For those who can remember back that far, Sunday August 2nd had "You can always count on me." Or, as the wet nurse might say, "Wean on me." The more people say "You can count on me" the less I believe it. You've just received a john ezra SCAM ALERT.

Love the cluing for STAYS. When she was in her early thirties, my wife was trying to collect on an old invoice from an English customer who was a bit of a toff. Her letters and phone messages left for him grew increasingly harsh and demanding (over some months). Finally, he wrote her an exasperated note (with cheque enclosed) accusing her of "wearing the whale-bone corset of the typical small businesswoman," which we both got a kick out of. And the toff has become a dear friend, even if he is the type who would indeed say, "You can always count on me," and never really mean it.
That was fun, thanks.

Just completed a Saturday puzzle from the archive.  

6000 puzzles solved
750 current streak
750 longest streak.

Re 34A (YOU CAN COUNT ON ME) - this was also the title of a wonderful movie released in 2000 starring Laura Linney, Mark Ruffalo, and Matthew Broderick.  It was nominated for two Academy Awards.  The plot revolves around a brother and sister who have taken very different paths in life struggling toward reconciliation.

Second appearance of YOUCANCOUNTONME in a short period of time. It’s an amazing 2000 film starring Laura Linney, Mark Ruffalo, and Matthew Broderick. I hope to see it clued as such one day. Kinda like the thrill I get when forgotten jazz great Etta Jones is the clue for ETTA rather than Etta James. Her “Don’t Go to Strangers” is a superb place to start. And her late-career “I’ll Be Seeing You” is one of the song’s greatest recordings.

I don’t know what it says about me that I confidently plonked in nuDIE RUN for 55A and needed crosses to add on basic articles of clothing. 

Very smooth sailing otherwise. The clueing was a little bit less straightforward than recent Fridays, however, which was very welcome and made for a more interesting solve. 

BESTRONG is what I believe used to be called a dook.

I liked it a lot. A few gimmes to give me a toe hold but enough sticky spots to make it interesting. I was wondering how I got YOUCANCOUNTONME so quickly, but as someone else pointed out maybe it was lingering in my head from Dr. McCoy’s quote from Sunday’s puzzle.

Who’s planning to use UNDIE RUNS on their next occasion of BAR TRIVIA?

Related question, using Deb’s observation: who here self-identifies as a shy person and would perform an undie run?!

Fast but fun. 

I like the clue for CUSS WORDS. Not because it's particularly tricky, but because it gives me an excuse to use the word "grawlix" (which I have just learned is also called an "obscenicon"). And the factoid about PANDAs was fun to learn.

Thanks, gents.

Me seeing UNDIERUNS:

I'm so glad my kids have outgrown the phase where I dread seeing those streaks in while preparing the laundry. Maybe someday they'll have to deal with my undie runs.

Also, that's really kind of a gross clue/answer for the NYT crossword. Surprised they went with it. Am missing something

...spends way to much time thinking about it...

Oh, wait. That's not at all what it means. Ha, it's actually kind of funny.

Fine for a Friday I felt.  It gave me a little trouble in the corners but not too much.  Not in love with undie runs but I'll accept that it might exist.

Cromulent.

GEE THANKS Rafael and Matthew.  I loved your puzzle!  Fun clues and nothing TACKy (no neaps, eras, oreos, or eons). If you ever need a recommendation, YOUCANCOUNTONME,  When you have another puzzle, by all means, come WRITEBACK—

(Everyone else loved it too—at least IASSUMESO).

This was fun. First pass while taking the dog out I was sweating like “where am I going to start?”

Then YOUCANCOUNTONME seemed like a no brainer that happened to fit, and it was an all downhill PR Friday for me. Funny how that works sometimes when you don’t see it right away.

Nice puzzle. Congrats as always to the constructors.
This was a fun puzzle. Thanks!

Not bad. I needed several lookups though to get crosses in places where my not quite being on the constructors' wavelength was hindering my solve:

STOWE - I know of the author but have never read anything by her so the quote was unfamiliar.

WONKA - I watch almost no movies, and I generally don't follow news on them; I googled what it was - a family musical! The horror! You can't get more un-Andrzej than that.

TSARS - the only connection I saw between the names was them being Eastern Slavic, possibly Russian. It turned out my main problem here was how you transcribe Slavic names in English: Alexis I only know as a female name, and one without a Polish equivalent. As I googled Alexis today I learned it was the male name I know as Aleksy.

CHANG - never heard of the author.

STOAT - I'm not good with animal names in English; I wanted the answer to be Sable, but once it became obvious that was wrong I broke down and looked up the answer. I knew the word after all, but it just wouldn't come to me today on its own...

I've never heard of an UNDIE RUN, but crosses gave it to me. I had no idea what it might mean. Thank you Deb for explaining it in the column. Now that I understand it, I don't like the clue, TBH. If an UNDIE RUN is akin to streaking, then walking fully clothed is akin to an UNDIE RUN. Isn't that a stretch?



**My wife and I are going on holiday on Sunday. I probably won't be posting for 3 weeks: I'll be breaking my routines to properly rest.**
21 minutes, and had to come back to it after watching a movie. Got really tripped up in the NW because I wanted 3D to be EIGHT way too badly
Bar Trivia was a new one for me. In the UK they are quiz nights. Is an undie run a real thing ?? lol. Nice puzzle
first friday ever in under 15.  am i getting better?  are puzzles getting too easy?  do bears bear?  do bees be(e)?  (bu)zzzzzzzzzzzzzzz...
UNDIERUN?? More of a mis-sprint than a mara-thong?
Pleased to make an appearance in the clues today ;)

Wow a Friday I actually enjoyed. Very little niche trivia.
Thanks!
great puzzle!

It truly didn't occur to me that undieruns might be an athletic event. First and only thought was skidmark related. It seems I wasn't the only one to misunderstand the intended relationship between streaks and undergarments. 😅

Seems the contents outweigh the discontents on this one. I liked it. The tiny superhuman Harriet Beecher visited the UK and went down a storm, way before Lycra was a thing. A surreal juxtaposition. It reminded me of Thailand for some reason. Maybe it was The King and I connection with stretchy fabric and forced labour in sweatshops. Weird.

My usual approach is a top-down solve. My first pass resulted in a mostly unsolved grid. Rethinking the clues, my solving was bottom to top with the NE corner taking some time to resolve. 

TGIF!

Fun, fast Friday.
Fanks.

Only a little over my average time. The southeast corner tripped me up a little. After yesterday's solve taking over twice as long as normal for me, today was fun. 

General question, is it normal for Thursday/Friday/Saturday solve times to be about the same? Those days each average about 21 minutes for me.
I love it on a Friday when Clue 1 is a gimme, and a wonderful person as well.

I'm just curious.  The other game I regularly play is Spelling Bee where it is actually forbidden to list solutions (acceptable words) in the comments.  Here, that is emphatically not the case...something I routinely forget.  I am always pleased that I can review comments in Spelling Bee before tackling that puzzle without running across something that would "help" me but I often start to read the comments here only to run into frequent posts listing solutions.  Anyone have any idea why it's permissible to list solutions here?  (Lest there be any confusion, this is NOT a complaint or a rhetorical question.)  Thanks.

Well, not at all an easy one for me, and had to look some things up. But managed to work through it. Nine debut answers in this one, but most of them quite familiar words or phrases. Surprised to see that. My puzzle find today - an unusual one. A Sunday from September 4, 2011 by Dana Delany and Matt Ginsberg with the title "That's Disgusting!" (and I don't at all understand that title). Anyway- all of the theme answers had exactly the same 'trick' or pattern. A couple of clue/answer examples: "Prank involving a hammer and nails?" CARPENTERANTIC "Vacation spot that's crazily busy?" THEISLEOFMANIC And some other theme answers: CLASSICACTIONSUIT RUSTICBUCKETS FINETUNIC ORIGINALCYNIC TOPICOFTHEMORNING And there were quite a few others. Here's the link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=9/4/2011&g=98&d=A See you tomorrow. ...

Like many other readers, I never would have thought of the "clean" explanation for the "undie" clue. 

I wonder if Will or any of the testers thought of the image I and so many others thought of. And if the editors did not, I wonder if now they are saying, "Oh, s---!"
I just want to register my petty outrage at being forced to write in Southern dialect (“CUSS WORDS”? How dare you) in order to complete this puzzle.

In describing the entry UNDIE RUNS, Deb writes, “They [i.e., streaks] are about running around in nothing but what the universe gave you.” 

I was unfamiliar with the use of “universe” in this context. A little research showed that it’s a substitute for the more common (to me) phrasing, “what God gave you” or “what Mother Nature” gave you or even the pithier “your birthday suit.”
Yep, liked this one a lot.

This was a very doable puzzle for me, under my average time and I didn't have to look up anything.

I'm normally not a fan of random phrase clues and answers (unless it serves a theme), but it didn't bother me too much in this crossword. There were some clever clues and funny answers.

I didn't know UNDIE RUNS were a thing! 😂

PS- I don't always comment but I try to read as many comments as I can every day. The community members here are rare group, so clever and (mostly) supportive. 👏
Enjoyable puzzle -- warts and all!

Once upon a time I actually ran in 5k races. Nowadays I just walk them. Does running or walking in your "undies" speed things up? What is the "undie" race world record? Who holds it? Where can I find "coed undie" races to walk in?

Glad others enjoyed it. This was one of those puzzles where the constructor and I were miles apart. That happens. I kept plugging away well past my average Friday time, with my enjoyment level waning by the minute. When I realized 55A was UNDIERUNS, I sighed, closed the app and just went on with my day.
Undie runs? TMI.

In my day, PANTY RAIDS were the "Pre-streaking Prank."  I am guessing UNDIE RUNS involved more sorts of lingerie.  (No, Deb; I'm betting that the owners of the UNDIEs aren't the ones RUNning around.)  Does that count as a CO-ED SPORT?

The novelist was hard to guess.  It sounded rather like TWAIN, and  the date was a slim possibility...but I needed 5 letters, and the other writers I came up with wouldn't fit... until the W appeared.

I BAKE cookies on a SHEET PAN, but I *MAKE* them in a mixing bowl (and in some cases) roll them out on a clean counter-top.  

Held off on 6A...just put in the POLE and waited for a crossing letter.  FLAG seemed unlikely. 

Nice challenge.
Enjoyed this one. A lot! Better than average time. Needed just a little help with names. Thanks!!

Bit of a tough one for me, 5 minutes over average at just under 30:00. First few passes left a mostly bare grid, but like some others experienced, YOUCANCOUNTONME broke the mid-west open and allowed me to work my way across the south fairly quickly, but breaking back up into the northern half took some doing. 

Still, no lookups for a Friday, so this nascent cruciverbalist maketh progress.

It was a great puzzle albeit difficult. The northeast got the best of me. 

There as certain clues that you think that you can never get. Even if given unlimited time. The TENTPOLE was one of those for me.
The mostly white animal threw me off

Do collaborations of xword pros produce hybrid vigor?   Looks that way.  Nice one and thanks.  

Serbian.

Cheez Louise, all this fuss about UNDIE RUNS? It's not what some of you think. It's just a wholesome activity that has taken place on college campuses since at least 2001. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Undie_Run I hadn't heard of them either, but it's exactly what I imagined it would be.
I'm not sure how being "mostly white" helps PANDAs hide in a bamboo forest. I've been to Sichuan, and it doesn't snow much there. They do seem to love it when it snows at the DC zoo.

The NW corner showed me no love right off the bat so I moved my usual starting point east. After that, things went swimmingly! I didn't get the PANDA clue so it just filled in with the crosses. If not for the head banging in the NW I coulda brought this baby under 10:00, surprised as all get out to see the clock stopped at 11:47! Thanks!
This could not be any closer to what should be expected in a Friday grid. Perfect difficulty, diverse, and well-balanced.
Just right for a Friday! Took me 45 minutes tho 😂 so I’m def not boasting about my solve time, but I enjoyed the challenge.

You say BAR TRIVIA. I say pub quiz. Both involve enormous amounts of gin (I suspect).

A good Friday puzzle; chewy but doable.
For 6A, I went with TENTPOLE almost immediately, though slightly nervously, and that helped gain an early foothold as much of the rest of the puzzle answers were slow coming.  Solid Friday fare.

I loved this puzzle, fell into place nicely and everything was on my wavelength. But then, I participated in an UNDIE RUN back in 2006! It’s tradition at my alma mater to do so during the first proper rain of the year. My campus was situated in a redwood forest so this was a more precarious situation than you might expect.
UNDIERUNS/streak had me thinking of something totally different 🫣

Perfect Friday grid for me. Slight misdirects that unraveled with the crosses. I had nYlon before LYCRA. I knew nylon didn’t sound right, so immediately tried the crosses. 3D OCTET fixed my answer right away. I also thought 6A could be some sort of hiking staff or TrekPOLE, but I left out the first four letters and just kept in POLE until I tried the crosses. I had cry before FAT and BAgTRIVIA fixed to BAR was my final fix. I had only the ending ME for 34A and confidently filled in YOU CAN COUNT ON. Was especially proud of that guess ☺️ All in all, I loved this start to my Friday. Thank you, Rafael and Matthew. More like this one please!
Happy Friday everyone! 🤩
Having never heard of UNDIE RUNS, I assumed that must be a gaming term for streaks of successful wins without dying. Ha!
For 6a I put in KINDLING right away. 8d NTH got me stuck on that until the end
I pretty confidently put in FIREWOOD for [stick around camp?]  and was sad when it became apparent that it was definitely wrong.  Ah well!  Nice puzzle, thanks!

Historical costumer here. Stays are NOT the support for a corset, they are a completely separate garment! (It's plural, like 'pants'.) You're thinking of bones or boning, which were once made of wood or whalebone and are now made of plastic or steel. 

Stays predate what we think of as corsets, which only showed up in the mid-1800s (and which were only ever used for the famous practice of waist-cinching and tight-lacing by a select few of high fashion elites, like the Kardashians of the day). Stays were worn for centuries before that, and contrary to modern popular misconception, most women liked them!

General, they were stiffened with bone strips or lots of long, skinny reeds, like pick-up sticks bundled into long narrow pockets which gave the stays flexibility. They laced up the back, as they had a wide plate in the center front called a "busk", which helped the stays serve their primary function of creating smooth lines under dresses, showing off expensive fabrics and embroidered stomacher panels, and supporting the weight of many layers of skirts (necessary in the days before central heating).

I can say from experience that they're also great back support for manual labor, great boob support for larger ladies, and because it's very difficult to do any waist cinching with them, they're very comfy. Think Renaissance Festival costumes and you're much closer!
One of those clever puzzles with obvious solves that nonetheless eluded me for quite some time.

Loved this one! Got very few on my first pass and ground to a halt half way through. Then I managed to piece together the central cross and suddenly things started clicking. Often with a d’oh! or aha! from me, thanks to the spiky clueing. Great job!

A very enjoyable solve, because it made me feel smart: Many clues suggested the right answer right away without my needing crossings. As a result this was close to my personal best time for a Friday NYT crossword.

Did not know OPTIC (noun) for a part of a microscope. Merriam Webster says it can mean any part of the optical system — lens, mirrors, etc. Did know "ocular" for the eyepiece. And did not know the term UNDIE RUNS, but I'm glad to learn that it is akin to the kind of "streaks" (streaking) that are relatively savory.

I've been away for a few weeks. I notice some changes to the comments section, not sure when they went into effect. But for some reason it no longer stores my name and location; I've made three brief comments today, and all three times (now four) I had to enter the information before I could hit the "submit" button.

weird.

The clue for "UNDIE RUNS", in the sense that I understood it, struck me as too crass for the NYT. 

But that minor bit of pearl clutching aside, a thoroughly enjoyable Friday solve - thanks Rafael and Matt!
What’s this American obsession with underwear pranks - undie run, wedgie…  I came from a culture afar where these things never happened :)
Nice puzzle. I have witnessed a few of those runs and they can be quite amusing.

I was very proud of myself for getting TENTPOLE and BARTRIVIA on my first RUN through!! The rest of the puzzle practically filled itself in, until I came back up to the north west corner and to a screeching halt. But don't worry, I didn't throw in the TROWEL! 

Looking back at it, I don't know why that little corner seemed so hard!  🤔

I so love to be on or in the water, and when I briefly thought sailing techniques might solve to TACoS, I thought I might need to learn how to sail!! Taco bout some real motivation to learn a new hobby!! ⛵🌮😍

One more late puzzle find. I've NEVER seen another one like this. A Sunday from June 14, 1987 by Maura B. Jacobson with the title: "MANGLED MIDDLE NAMES." Here are some clue/answer examples: "Actress idolized by leathernecks?" EVAMARINESAINT "Author of Hindu fairy tales?" HANSKRISHNANANDERSEN "Poet who wrote "Hair"?" JAMESWITHCOMBRILEY "Composer of "Pump and Circumstance"?" JOHNFILLUPSOUSA "Publisher who managed fairways?" WILLIAMRANGOLFHEARST "Writer of jazz anthems?" FRANCISSCATKEY Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=6/14/1987&g=65&d=A ...

Fun and breezy. Was kind of surprised that I was done in 19m 30s.

It had some nice challenges, but they fell into place a bit too easily for my taste.

I am guessing that the highly skilled solvers here blew through this one.

So I interpreted 55A Events akin to streaks in a very different way.  Think about streaks on underwear to know exactly where my mind went.  Glad I was wrong but still think my idea is funny, if not gross.

My sister attended Princeton in the late 80’s/early 90’s. They held the Nude Olympics every winter. Some chose to wear their UNDIEs so they wouldn’t freeze their tender bits. She sent me a tshirt that showed each event with stick figure people and black bars across their appropriate regions. I lost it in one of our moves, but still laugh thinking about it. I wonder if Princeton still holds this time honored tradition? Inquiring minds want to know…

Got stuck on the top left corner. I guess with SATE  I don’t think of being STUFFed, but the actual definition disagrees with me. I always thought of it as the perfect amount to satisfy an appetite. I also had EIGHT instead of OCTET, which didn’t help!

Oh... and even one more late puzzle find. Again, I've never seen another one like this. Another one by Maura B. Jacobson, from April 21, 1974 with the title "By No Means." All the theme answers started with the word: "No" Some examples: "No musical" THEFIDDLERINTHEBASEMENT "No book" CATCHERINTHEVODKA "No author" WINTERSETMAUGHAM "No body of water" LAKEINFERIOR "No hero" LAWRENCEOFISRAEL "No opera" THEHAIRDRESSEROFSEVILLE And... one with an answer that I particularly enjoyed: "No bridge bid" EIGHTNOTRUMP And there were more. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=4/21/1974 ...
Glad others liked this one. :)
Re 55A, here in San Francisco we have an annual "Santa Skivvies Run" which benefits the SF AIDS Foundation. I haven't participated, but I did enjoy taking photos of it once :-)
For all of us old guys. PLUTO IS A PLANET!
1D summed it up quite succinctly

Just to pick a nit, If snake eyes are "rare," they're no more so than any other roll.

⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

The fill seems to me ornery and/or overwrought, not a fun sort of challenge; indeed, over the last couple years, one can notice what a wide latitude the NYT team is granting to long-time, multi-published cruciverbalists…maybe more in the interest of showing off the verbal creativity of the puzzle designers ( and the mentoring skills of editors?), than furnishing puzzle solvers with fun challenges. For me and many, the leitmotif of puzzles like these is a cross between “See how clever I ( the designer) am” and “ Gotcha”. Boring.

As someone who has been doing crosswords for a number of years now I like to boast about how crosswording has made my mind more flexible, able to imagine different possibilities when the first answer doesn’t seem to work.

And then I fill in “eight” in answer to a clue about the planets and stubbornly cling to it even though I can’t fill anything else around it. Sigh. Perhaps one day I will learn.

And to all of you who thought undie runs were unfortunate remainders left in underwear: thanks for the visual.

I loved the tacks (and jibes) from my windsurfing years.

Aren't pandas mostly black with white? Was that clue meant to evoke the zebra riddle?

Face plant reminded me of last year visiting the Acropolis. At least four people ate it while navigating those grounds during our stay. The dark side of me wanted to laugh, but it wasn't very funny, nor were the injuries. 

There are several components to a microscope. There are two types of lenses in microscopes, according to Ramapo H.S.’s very own Mr. Pohl (stretch); the ocular and objective lenses. Are we supposed to consider the whole unit as an optic device? Hank Pohl was one of *the* best teachers in Ramapo and a surfing legend in NJ‘s LBI beaches. He knew Bunsen burners, Erlenmeyer flasks and microscopes and what “we lousy kids” needed to prepare for life.

The prism clue drew me right to Dark Side of the Moon. But I did like the solution, which reminded me of my putting on a Classical music CD yesterday while working on my model car. From Capriccio Italien all the way to Poet and Peasant Overture, the paint job on the car looks super.

Way to the left had me thinking of the Latin sinistral and dextral. Being left-handed, I'm considered sinister, which makes me ominous, creepy and disturbing. Shouldn't I be highly insulted at Big Word for the label they placed on me? Just, wow.

Wow I just finished up a puzzle in the archives that I thought was really cute and clever. Turns out it was almost universally hated, based on the comments! August 3, 2022.

Oh well,  isn't the first time and it won't be the last time...  If you need me, I'll just be out here walkin' on my lonely road. Har!!

I walk a lonely road
The only one that I have ever known
Don't know where it goes
But it's home to me, and I walk alone

Today's soundtrack brought to you by 3D. I saw Cyndi Lauper last night (amazing!) and among the mesh skirts and neon was a shirt that said "In My Day There Were Nine Planets." The opener was Jake Wesley Rogers, and while I knew a little about him (EXTREMELY engaging performer with a great live show), I didn't know his song "Pluto." It made me wonder if the guy in the shirt was a fan or just nostalgic like the rest of us. https://youtu.be/OZSIrxZziCM?si=QH13jj85I_6rJWh_
As a recent grad from UCLA, UNDIERUN was almost a gimme! Surprised to read the comments today but it shows solvers are of all ages.

I loved this puzzle - not a hard solve (finished 13 minutes faster than my average), but so many clever clues and misdirection. Lots of backspacing for me after getting stuck in the NW and elsewhere. Fun!
I love this puzzle! Really fun clues. Haters going to hate.

I’ve worked with microscopes plenty, never have I referred to any component as an “optic” (singular).” I know it’s technically in the dictionary but it feels quite clunky. I’m probably just being persnickety.
Got bogged down in the top line because I was convinced “Stick around camp?” was “kindling.” Got to the TENTPOLE eventually.

I loved this wonderful fun puzzle. It was a joy to solve. The clues were clean and the wordplay clever. Thank you Mr. Musa and Mr. Stock. I really enjoy a smooth cohesive puzzle. Y'all rock. 

I laughed too Deb when I realized the "rounds" were more than questions. 

Y'all have a lovely week end. Stay safe, cool, and hydrated. ✌️
@Mike you are amazing coming up with apt non mots every night. Look forward to what you come up with
@Mike puns just make me number than I was before

@Mike
You must be wired for puns. I have to rack my brains before something clicks.

@Mike

Punsters line up now.  Mike will call queue later.

@Deb Amlen
Oh, that's too square...

@Mike How many people on this thread actually have an abacus? I reckon you can count them on the fingers of one hand. 

I just realized that an abacus is a digital calculator. And numbers are abacusswords. I guess the swear root of pun is pun!

@Deb Amlen
I’m logopaígniophobic .

@D M Mojo

3.1416
@Jim - 42
@Jim 🥧😋😆
@Maverator that’s exactly what happened to me.

@D M Mojo

Yes I had to do the NW last as well, which is how I like it. Tried ELIOT before STOWE for one thing.

@SP

I tried TWAIN at first. Seemed plausible to me.
@Teresa that was my first guess also.

@DW

That's the kind of longer answer that I just can't get myself to put in without a few crosses.
@DW I first first confidently entered "hothouses", but the crosses quickly nixed that.
It seemed a little sticky early on, but once answers started coming it filled quite quickly, at just over half of my average Friday time.

@George

It was a bit on the lighter side of average for a Friday, IMO, but “too easy”? Definitely too hard for a Wednesday and where else would you put it? It’s a quality puzzle and certainly deserves to go somewhere. Think about it this way, no matter how you slice it, half the puzzles on any given day will be below average in difficulty by definition.

@LBG
I suspect SP meant to say “median” instead of *average*. Of course, your point is valid.

Hardroch,

Jay may or may not have meant "median," 
but I'm pretty sure SP meant "average," 
as in this usage:
 
Difficulty
Average

Median Solve Time
14:42

Median Solver
10% faster
⚡64% of users solved faster than their Friday average.
34% solved much faster (>20%) than their Friday average.
🐢36% of users solved slower than their Friday average.
15% solved much slower (>20%) than their Friday average.

@Marshall Walthew

Speaking of microscopic parts and undieruns, anyone see the first episode of the new "South Park" season?

@Marshall Walthew
I assume we all appreciated the appearance of 41A along with 23D. Very tidy, gentlemen.

@Marshall Walthew
After reading the clue for 16A, I was just relieved it wasn’t EYELENS again…

@SBK


Missed that entirely.  Good catch.

@Mike R
In keeping with yesterday’s theme, if you wear Fruit of the Loom when doing UNDIERUNS then streakers run FRUITLESSLY

@SP

The trick is to jockey for position while keeping your hanes free.  You hope what you catch won't be VD.

@B,

I saw what you did there.
@Swift What, you don't have a rong you like best?
@Swift. Got DOOKed here myself.
@Andrzej I just laughed out loud as well 🤣 My kids just rolled their eyes at me 🙄

@john ezra
I like that one can have a tiff with a toff and still end up with a bff

@john ezra

I remember less random trivia now than I did when I first started solving NYT crosswords in 2016.  But my solve rate now is much higher than then -- close to 100%.  I learned to fill in the answers I did not know by other means than looking them up.

Jim,
I distinguish between a solve (unassisted) and a completion (with assistance), but unlike Mike I accept that "streak" may refer to either. I do prefer that streakers report which mode they employ.

Andrzej,
Constructors may like certain "niche" things, but the editors are supposed to make the trivia "fair" (see Natick).

Andrzej,

The NYT Crossword has always been a test of literacy. The "literature" it tests has broadened somewhat over the years, but solvers have always been expected to know things.

If Thursdays trick isn’t clear right away,
it’s generally my longest solve time. 
Not a big difference, but it can be with a very
novel rebus or gimmick.

Friday and Saturday average time is 
right in line with Wednesday, for me.

@Andy G

I’d say the pattern of solve times varies by the individual. The type of thinking required for Thursday puzzles is different from that of Friday and Saturday puzzles. Thursdays take longer for some people for that reason. But my solve time curve is exactly where it’s intended to be, with Monday the easiest and Saturday the hardest, and each day moving upwards in average solve time.
@CCNY thanks

@Andy G for me, if I plot my avg times through the week (placing Sunday at the end), it’s a surprisingly smooth upward progression, with Thursday being the only day obviously out of place (a little above the curve, but still below my Friday avg.)

Too bad there’s no way to post a pic here, but here are my avg times (NORMALIZED to 1 🤓):

0.18, 0.25, 0.35, 0.56, 0.62, 0.81, 1.0

1429 puzzles solved, 

My BEST times are not quite as neat, but similar, all increasing by day of week with the exception that my Friday best is faster than my Thursday best.

@Dave

WO(4)-vocabulary item with its own definition.

@Dave  The column you are commenting to here contains tricky answers, so the presumption is that you've already seen those unless you are commenting on a column you haven't read. (Which many of us are guilty of, but this still sets the expectation.) 

For Spelling Bee, you only have to pass the hints page to get to the comments, so the presumption is that you are looking for a new level of hints, but not yet for the actual answers.

Having never heard of an UNDIE RUN (although well aware of streaking), I didn't make the connection, even when the answer was filled in.

If you've never seen a phrase, one guess is as good as another about what it means.

@Brendan

I've found references that state that CUSS in U.S. usage or informal, but nothing that says Southern.  It's just one example of the very common action of r-dropping, seen in the words "bass" (the fish), which was spelled with an r in Middle English, and a similar word without the b, which still uses the r in British usage.
Brendan, No regional restriction or preference noted here, and I've heard it as much in the North as in the South. https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/cuss
